remixed_from.title: Quick-Fit X carriage and Extruder - LM8UU

description.text:
For Day 5 of 30 days of creativity ( #30DoC ) I give you another addition to the Quick-fit family, here is a Quick-fit X carriage and mount for the Printrbot. Designed for any extruder's that can go on my Quick-Fit X carriage.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19590 ** - Sketchup files now uploaded :)

Make your Printrbot easier to switch extruder's and give yourself a new X mount. Print out the two plates and replace the X carriage on the Printrbot. It also needs the Quick-Fit catch from Here - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19590
Print a Quick-Fit Extruder, see link. It's designed to be used with Extruder's that use the Quick-Fit X carriage.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19590 I also re-made the X Axis mount with 3 Linear bearings instead of just 2. It all fits and operates on the Printrbot, but limited testing so I'm going to say it's a work in progress until I have done some more printing with it. Made for Day 5 of 30 days of creativity ( #30DoC ) http://30daysofcreativity.com/ See my blog for updates and other printing advice - http://richrap.blogspot.co.uk/2012/06/quick-fit-extruder-mount-and-x-axis-for.html

author: Schildkroete1

title: Hexagonal rubber-banded armour plate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
As part of an outfit I'm working on for a festival, I've been looking at the various printable plate/chainmail offerings floating around Thingiverse and other places for a while.
Unfortunately, nothing quite fit what I needed - some of the print-in-place stuff takes aeons to print and is difficult to connect separate sheets together of afterwards, or relies on precision levels I couldn't always be confident of through my printer.

As such, when I've been designing this, it's been aimed for a reasonably solid print with minimal cleanup afterwards, and each panel is connected to others via loom bands (or something with a similar size) as they're cheaper than orthotic bands generally.

Whilst the central pin is large enough to take connections from 6 plates surrounding it, if it gets fiddly or you've connections that keep springing off, the push-lock plate should snap into the back of the hex and securely clamp things down.
However, that said, I've done lots of static assemblies of this with no problems but haven't tested in an actual worn outfit. Panels of various sizes have happily survived hanging and flexing, but this may be updated if tweaks are required.
I'd recommend printing out 7 plates and arranging them as a hex and generally beating up on them a bit to confirm your print state and bands are compatible.

Edit: I've added a 5-side version in case anyone wants to do geometries where the natural flow of the plates doesn't support it as they flex.
Please note that these are untested live, and are in a "weak" configuration as far as the movement of the rubber bands go, so your success will depend very much on the quality of your rubber bands.
Also, they're quite fiddly...

Edit: Added half-plate so you can neaten up edges and more easily prevent edge panels being caught on things.

Edit: Added a pentagonal locker for those plates by request, and a composite 2x2x2 hex-plate for if you need... I dunno, a solid surface or something.

Printer Brand:

CEL

Printer:

Robox

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm, 0.4mm nozzle

Infill:

30%

Notes:

This design's aimed to be self-supporting, so the angles are set to 40% to avoid droop.
There's a chamfer on all undersides to minimise elephant-foot, so let me know if there's an issue with that and I can add a version without it.

Cleanup should be minimal if your printer is happy - I've taken to running a thin knife-blade through the gap to add the rubber-band to catch any overprinting and avoid having to fiddle around when you've got a plate half-connected to a bunch of others.
Designed in Autodesk Fusion 360.

comments.text: This was great for my master chief cosplay!!!
comments.author: Lorgo044

comments.text: Glad to hear it - post pics! ;)
comments.author: Lorgo044

comments.text: How do you put the rubber bands on?, where
comments.author: Kyle10kms

comments.text:
The easiest way I found, especially as panels start to get larger and less wieldy, is put the loom band straight between the two centre pins of the plates you're trying to connect. It should then lie either side of the "legs" on the edges of each plate.
Then, with one thumb (or digit of your choice) on the centre pin and the legs of one plate, and one thumb on the centre pin of the other, move and spin the other plate so you're guiding the two strands of the rubber band through the diagonal gap between the legs; it should ping through with a bit of resistance, and hopefully not fall out of its own accord.
Then swap your thumb positions, and repeat for the other tile.
comments.author: Kyle10kms

comments.author: misyth

comments.text: That's really cool,  do you perhaps have a recommended size of rubber bands?  On a side note, would o-rings help with life span?
comments.author: Johaboo

comments.text:
I'm using generic loom bands which seem to have about a 12mm ID, so things of that nature should be reasonable.
As for O-rings, yes, they probably would, but assembly might be more difficult due to their profile and I imagine it might make panels much more expensive; one of the reasons I went with loom bands is they're very cheap for a bag of generic ones.

description.text:
This is a mount to hold a lens filter for the FITFORT Action Camera. At the time of design, there were no lens filters specifically designed for this camera and the round lens cover made it incompatible with filters designed for the GoPro's square lens cover.

This particular mount is designed for use with these filters but would work with any brand as long as the dimensions are the same.

In addition to the printed parts, this design requires 2 nut and bolt sets. I'm using a bolt about 4mm in diameter x 2cm in length and it fits very snuggly and requires a screwdriver to attach. This helps it stay secure even if the nut loosens.

description.text: dallor eagle

print_settings.Notes:: I printed the bottom half of the knob without supports and it managed to do it just fine; however, depending on your printer (and material) you may need to use them.

description.text:
I designed this shift knob for my Subaru, because I wanted something that was weighted (for 'easier' shifting); the standard shift knob was only 196g, and that simply wouldn't do. Thus, I found a cylinder of lead that was lying around and fitted it into the center of the design, which brought the weight up to a hefty 512g.

Although this design is highly specific, perhaps someone can use all or part of it to improve theirs.

Hardware needed:
(1x) M12x1.25 standard or Nyloc nut (for the actual shifter shaft)
(8x) M3x35 bolts (for attaching the two halves of the knob together)
(8x) M3 standard nuts (function as embedded nuts to keep the halves secure)

After installing it, my shifts have become slightly smoother and even after sitting in the sun all day it hasn't lost its rigidity.

UPDATE: (2017-08-14) Still shifting wonderfully and has survived a few 40C days in the sun; a testament to PETG's temperature tolerance...

Printer:

HyperCube

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50% cubic, 4 shells

Notes:

I printed this in PETG for its strength and heat tolerance (since it sits in my car all day and becomes hot and PLA would've become too soft).

I printed the bottom half of the knob without supports and it managed to do it just fine; however, depending on your printer (and material) you may need to use them.

Installation

I designed the M3 nuts to be hot pressed into their cavities as well as the M12 nut; however, you may want to double check the size of your M12 nut when you buy it. When I first tried to hot press it in, it was simply too small, so I had to remeasure, print, and press it again.

Also, I used a 3mm drill bit to carefully clean up the holes of both halves, as PETG can be fairly "stringy".

print_settings.Notes:: I set 5 layers on top and bottom, as well 2 outside perimeters.

title: Garmin 73SV swivel mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Garmin does not make a swivel mount for the 73SV. You can only tilt it on one plane with the stock mount. Not rotate it side to side.

This is a ratcheting swivel mount for the Garmin 73 SV. It works in conjunction with the stock 73SV mount.

This should fit any of the Garmin 7x SV series.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Duplicator 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Printed with simplify 3d with auto supports. Worked great. Have only prototypes in PLA. ABS would probably be best. But I'll see how PLA holds up.

I set 5 layers on top and bottom, as well 2 outside perimeters.

Building steps

4x #10 1" tapered head wood screws; stainless (mount to boat)
4x #10 24x1" bolts and nuts; stainless (connect unit to the mount) ;
1x 1" M10 bolt stainless
2x M10 washer (or close fitting) stainless
1x M10 nylon lock nut; stainless

4x 5/16" ball bearings
4x springs (I used springs from mechanical pencils as I had some; not quite as wide of a spring as I wanted but it works well) The stronger the spring the better it will latch. You can self fit springs once you have printed the base up to the width of the hole; but I would make sure the bearing sits nicely in the top of the spring. So something a bit smaller than the hole would be best.

I picked up all the parts at my local home depot.

Recommend cleaning out the holes on the side of the pivot mount so bearings fit well before starting assembly; they should be able to roll in and out of the holes

Mount is constructed into 2 parts. Top mount which connects to the stock Garmin mount. And the smaller pivot mount which contains the spring/ball bearings in the holes on the main shaft.

Once printed 1st you will need to insert the springs/ball bearings. Put the two pieces together as you see in the one rendering (partial assembly). While holding them together angle the pivot stand away on one axis so you can only see ONE hole at a time. Place the spring into the hole and follow it with the bearing. Then close the gap you made to insert the parts. Rotate the pivot mount quarter turn and do the next hole with a spring and ball bearing.

Once complete be sure to NOT separate the parts or the parts will go flying.

Place one M10 washer in the top of the mounting bracket inside the counter sunk hole and then place the M10 bolt through the washer and out the bottom of the pivot mount.

Flip the mount over so you can see the bottom while holding the bolt. Place the other washer on the bolt sticking through the bottom and screw on the M10 lock nut. Tension these just enough so it still spins freely without any loose play.

Place the #10 nuts in the counter sunk holes on the bottom of the top mount. I found it was best to thread the nuts on to the screw and then push them into the counter sinks on the bottom of the swivel mount then back out the screw to leave the nut in place. I did this to seat the nuts as deep as possible into the counter sunk area.

Place the Garmin mount over the swivel mount we just created. It can only fit one direction due to the radius which sticks out from one side of the part. Use the #10 24x1" screws and nuts to secure the two together. The #10 screws are tight fitting in the Garmin mount. They thread through it, be sure to align the mount correctly before starting the screws. And start the screws over the holes in the mount we just made. Place all 4 screws through and tighten them until secure.

Use the 4x #10 tapered wood screws to secure the mount to the boat. I found rotating the swivel would give best access to screw in the mount.

description.text:
This is a 3D model of the Munsell colour system that specifies complex colour space based on three dimensions: hue, value (lightness), and chroma (color purity).
(see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Munsell_color_system).

It is a great way to use up all those filament ends and looks great on display!

(The second image image is from Wikipedia and the acknowledgment is here:
CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=1955750)

I used Rigid Ink, Faberdashery and Colorfabb filaments as well as bundles off Amazon etc so I could get a good colour representation

description.text:
This is the final version of the mudguard. Its now longer and wider than when i first started making them. This is because after i tested it in rain, the wheel got dirty even thought i stayed dry. This have now been fixed.

Its reccomended to print it at an angle to ensure that the locks are strong and the shell keeps together.

To put it on the wheel you simply slide it on. The sharp angle in the middle makes it easy to center.

Yes

02

Infill:

80%

Notes:

Only tested in abs.
Use a raft so it's easier to remove after the print is done. The walls on the mudguard is very thin and without a simple raft that easily peels off, it might break when removing.

I also reccomend to give it an Acetone waping. This makes the layers melt together and the overall strength will go up.

title: Bahtinov focus mask for Sigma 150-500 zoom lens

description.text:
This is a focusing aid used for astrophotography. This particular one is made specifically for use with a particular zoom lens, the Sigma 150-500 APO DG OS used at full focal length. The mask fits into the lens hood - it just slots in. It helps you accurately focus your lens by mounting it in front of the lens and pointing the camera at a bright star. You then see a particular patern in the viewfinder or liveview and adjust the focus manually untill the pattern is symmetrical. Once you have achieved that you remove the mask and the camera is ready for shooting. Its use is described in more detail in this wikipedia article:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahtinov_mask Credits go to the creator of this website:
http://astrojargon.net/MaskGenerator.aspx It is the calculator there that created the correct pattern - I then just extruded it into three dimensions.

Just print in black ABS.  
Scale down to one tenth size in the slicer before printing.
Be careful when peeling it off the build plate as it breaks quite easily.
The slots may need some trimming.

comments.text: Hello, first time messing around with 3d printing. When I open this file, it is way larger than the sigma lens hood. x:1307mm y:1172mm. The y should be closer to 114mm. Would you be able to tell me the exact x,y,z measurements? Thanks.

you need to scale down the model to one tenth size. I always make the models on Sketchup 10 times normal size to avoid some problems with small details. I export it at that size and then scale down in the slicer.

I just printed wheel2.  That and solid are dimensionally incorrect.  The axle hole is too large and doesn't print well without support.  The are way more massive than the official wheels.

I have seen several article on wheel modification, there are lots of things that could be done to make the wheel more competitive.  In this round I'm just shooting for close to official wheel.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
I just picked up the new Apple Magic Keyboard with Numeric Keypad for my home office. There are commercial solutions for binding the old Magic Trackpad with the old wireless keyboard, but there wasn't a simple and elegant solution for the new ones.

I didn't want to add significant height or bulk so I made this tray set. I don't know if it works with the Magic Keyboard WITHOUT the numeric keypad, but it turned out great for the one with.

It can be a little tricky getting all 3 pieces set under just right, but once you've got them in the right place they stay keep the two pieces bound together.

They are also symmetrical which makes them ambidextrous. As you can see from the photo, I keep the track pad on my left, and a high resolution corded mouse on my right, but you can flip the pieces to work with the trackpad on the right.

Let me know if you like it and if it works with the original Magic Keyboard.

Any particular reason for using functions to hold the shapes, rather than a variable?
Only thing I can see is that they are like a constant, but that hardly matters.
Performance?
comments.author: MichaelAtOz

comments.text: The reason that the shapes are contained in functions is that I'm using a tool that we wrote to export paths and models from Blender to OpenSCAD's polygon and polyhedron formats. That exporter uses functions because they are a cleaner/more modular way to reference the data when including/using it in separate files. It also gives us some more flexibility when exporting shape keys. Here's the Blender addon if you want to try it out: https://github.com/graphicsforge/io_mesh_openscadhttps://github.com/graphicsfor...

Made one in PET.
The centered hole of the model does not fit the BCN3D. The photo of the installed part has an off-center hole, which would move the stepper about 1/4". The model and the photo are clearly not the same part.
As printed, installed in place of right extruder, with the latest (Oct2017) BondTech, the Y-carriage crashes into the tension lever on the BondTech. I unscrewed the tension screw, so the lever could move out of the way, and the carriage still hits the Bowden tubes. They just sit too far from the back wall and the carriage cannot reach the limit switch. Rather than cutting down the BondTech lever and moving the limit switch, I punted and re-located the BondTech to the outside back wall of the BCN3D, using the bracket as printed.

Spool holder for 2020 Aluminium extrude printers, such as Hybercubes. Fits to the inside corner and requires 4 x M5 slot nuts and 10mm bolts. It also needs a section of 8 mm bar or threaded bar and 2 x M3 nuts and 10mm bolts to clamp the bar in position. The bar needs to be long enough to clamp in the holder and reach through the full width of the spool, 150mm is more than adequate.

This design can easily take 2 spools and accepts the spool holders I've designed.

description.text:
My daughter asked for a boat to use in the bath. There are a couple other boat models on here but I couldn't find one that would stay afloat when loaded up with Little Pet Shops and My Little Ponys. This one floats really well, with or without things in it.

remixed_from.title: Parametric Peristaltic Pump with optional mount and roller holes

title: Peristaltic pump 15 sun gears 3 planets, 10 gears, 70mm diameter

description.text: So, the good news is that I can now get the pumps to print reliably. Complex parts of the print kept jamming my extruder. Printing at dead slow speed for the shells (13mm/s or less) finally resolved this. To prevent slumping, the openSCAD code had to be set to prevent overhangs, and despite the resulting layer of phantom mesh which others have already remarked on, it still prints. However even with larger teeth and cogs, it still tends to make a meal of actually turning with the tygon in place and keeps skipping teeth. Eventually two planets bump into each other and it self-destructs, even for quite a large pump size! The video is quite spectacular. It gamely keeps pumping up until the end! Perhaps this design is just unworkable?? Any thoughts??

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Notes:

3 shells. Shell print speed of 13mm/s or less

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/RCmQVxCjcEk" ></iframe>
pumps but self-destructs!

comments.text:
Look at Blood transfusion, Dialysis, Peristaltic pump designs
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peristaltic_pump
https://www.pmdcorp.com/resources/case_studies/4
Observe the support structure
Try a center support for the drive motor
And 2 support ring in both sides of the 3 gears to control the spacing.
comments.author: Hagie1

comments.text:
I have designed several peristaltic pump designs for my company. (Can't share them as they belong to the company.) My observation is that you need to pump a frame to locate the center spindle and anchor it relative to the frame. Obviously, you have to have a little clearance at each tooth. However, if the center moves too far to one end, all the clearance can build up at one tooth interface, hence the slipping. Try making a solid plate on each side (cut out holes for viewing) kind of like a cup that encircles the body, then provides a bearing hub for the drive shaft. Keeping that in place might help a lot!
Congratulations on a cool idea! I just buy geared down motors with massive torque!
comments.author: DavidBarbe

comments.text:
Hi
I have not printed this so I can't prove it but I think it would work if the planets were fixed in place in relation to each other, eg print a triangle to hold them in place ( if there were three planets). I think there would be some movement but it would be kept small with a retaining triangle but you would have to allow a greater space between the planets and the sun to allow it to take up the movement.
comments.author: elric1000

comments.text: Thanks for your interest elric1000. Actually I had the same idea myself which is one of the reasons I switched to XZO's design. He/she added holes to the planets to save weight, but I have been wondering if these could support axles for a triangular frame. However, given the extreme stress that the planets are under - you can really hear them creak and crack - it would have to be a low friction axle, and you would probably need to add a ball race bearing etc, which would make everything unfeasibly large. I may still try it some time (a PTFE lined axle perhaps?)
comments.author: elric1000

title: PTFE Tube Guillotine Cutter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Getting a perfect 90° cut on PTFE tubing is a royal pain in the .... yeah. If it's not perfect, you are just asking for leakage, which is NEVER good in any situation, especially in a 3d printer hotend. You could take the heatblock apart and trim the tubing flush against the metal sleeve, but that requires disassembling the hotend which isn't particularly fun, either. What you need is the PTFE Tubing Guillotine! Simply slide your tubing through the hole until it sits firmly inside to rear pocket and slice. Easy peasy.

You will need a 25mm (1") long 3mm bolt, a 3mm nut and two (at least) 6mm long 3mm bolts as well as a standard Stanley-type knife blade.

UPDATE
As requested, I have added another version of the base that has the PTFE tubing hole cut all the way through to aid in removal of the scrap piece. This is v3 of the base.

UPDATE PART 2
As requested. I have added another version of the base that has a 45° angle guide in addition to the straight through guide. This is the v4 of the base.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

You can print the base with less infill if you like - 20% or 30% even, but the arm and the keeper really need to be 100%. It doesn't use much more filament and the additional print time is negligible. Rotate the arm and the keeper 90° so that they are laying flat on their backs to avoid the need for supports.

comments.text: Just a thought to make a little extra use out of this, do you think you could add a little 45 degree guide to help cut filament at an angle to make it easier to insert in the unused extra space the blade comes down on ? I would remix it if i had any skills at all with design but I struggle enough with just printing the things :-p

print_settings.Notes:: I recommend using a 20 layer brim and 100% infill, since this is a part requiring constant load under friction that should not bend or deform. Of course, this all depends on the material being used. Be careful not to push the bearing all of the way in, or it will grind against the back face when turning. The soft plastic will deform to fit the new shape after a while anyway, but just a heads up.
print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text:
This is a remix of the https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:305363 608 bearing mount. I saw that he had made it so that there needs to be a hole drilled, and supports were needed. I made this one so that the 8mm rods that are being used in your 3d printer setup simply have to be trimmed to the correct size. The 608 bearing with the dimension 22x7x8mm bore now fit flush with the inner surface, with no hole drilling needed. The fit should be tight enough that the bearing slides in, maybe tap it in carefully with a hammer, and then mount the 8mm rod.

This design eliminates entirely the need for supports since one side is flat, and provides enough backing so that the bearing will not pop out. If you like, you can put a bit of cyanoacrylate (aka crazy glue) on the bearing to hold it in, and on the 8mm rod to make sure it does not pop out. It takes 5mm screws.

Thanks to the original creator for saving me nearly $100 in parts.You will need 608 bearings with the referenced dimensions for this to work. This is designed for a rod mounted gantry in the style of the Ultimaker TM. I also included the Blender file if you would like to modify the ends to fit a 2020 extrusion.

Enjoy!

Robo 3D

I recommend using a 20 layer brim and 100% infill, since this is a part requiring constant load under friction that should not bend or deform. Of course, this all depends on the material being used. Be careful not to push the bearing all of the way in, or it will grind against the back face when turning. The soft plastic will deform to fit the new shape after a while anyway, but just a heads up.

I'm printing it as we speak at 75% x and y dimensions and 100% on the z, no raft or brim, with supports using Simplify3d.

title: Front Grip resized for Caliburn
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Slight changes to SBSExtensions' grip1 front grip to better fit the full MR_Foregrip version of the Caliburn pump action Nerf blaster. The grip is a nice fit for the Caliburn, but needed some adjustments to support the pressures from being used as a pump-action.

The longer grip version moves back the grip-railing end so that the grip contacts the front of the pump-railing to support during priming. The screw keeps the grip in place during a return push of the pump.

The shorter version cuts off about an inch from the back of the grip and moves the screw hole. Both versions will work with around an M4 screw. Pictured is the shorter grip version with an M5 screw because that was the only one I had laying around.

author: CarstenD

description.text:
The Gyroid is a periodic minimal surface discovered in the '70s.  Everyone seems to love showing off their powder printers by making these, so I decided to see if it was possible to make one on a Makerbot.  Turns out as long as the scale is small enough, these overhangs and bridges print quite well with no support.  
I was printing these dualstrusion gyroids at the Seattle Mini Makerfaire on my new Replicator (they only take about 30 minutes).  There's also a couple of single color versions included.  You can stack these in all three dimensions to form a continuous surface.

The dualstrusion version comes out nice, but I found I had to do some knife work on it.  The Replicator (at least with PLA) leaves some ooze when doing dualstrusion.  There is one overhanging point that can't be printed properly even in a single color, but it's small and easily removed.  
I made the Gyroid shape in Matlab using gyroid.m and a tool from the file exchange that writes STLs.  I used OpenSCAD to adjust those files into the ones I print.  GyroidThin, Thick and Half are the intermediates between Matlab and OpenSCAD, so you can make whatever you want out of this surface.

description.text:
This is my solution for TRONXY X3 bed wobbling problem.
Based on kencam's solution, I tried to maximize distance between the 400mm rods, allow for both belts orientations (vertical and horizontal) and keep original TRONXY X3 design (motor, end limit switch) as much as possible.
Bed attaches with 4x M3x16mm (not in the pictures, original M5 were used for orientation). Acrylic bed was drilled with a 3mm bit.

Stepper Motor Support (without central 2020 extrusion): https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2437197
Rod Supports (Low Profile): https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2437820
Bronze bushings (8mm x10mm x10mm) support: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2437855
Bed cable relief: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2437865
Carbon Reinforcement: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2501346

(belt tensioner (not my design): https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2021999)

No

More parts coming!

This is a case for the MinnowBoard Max Turbot computer board.
The case was designed using OpenScad.

Four M3 x 30 mm bolts need to joint base to the lid
Four short PC screws are needed to hold board in to the bottom tray.
Set variables to true / false within the SCAD script to remove / add case holes as needed.
Change the screw hole sizes to use different screws.
Increase tray depth to accomadate different lures.

A modular board game player assistant. Use as few or as many as you want to assist you in keeping tabs on your board game pieces. I have included the base box for those who would like to design their own to match with the rest.

Use 8x3 mm magnets. If you make the square on each piece face upward and place the magnets in the same direction each way you can then arrange the boxes however you like.

Use finer resolution on the boxes with circles / ramps for a smoother finish.

Yet Another Fidget Spinner! You print the outer part twice, and the inner part once. Three, 11 mm. diameter ball bearing balls go in the outer holes, a standard skateboard ball bearing in the middle. The 11mm balls need to be clicked in place in the inner part before you glue on the outer parts. I included the Freecad file for easy customization.

This thing is to avoid the PTFE tube get back to the extruder due to retraction settings.

Easy and simple.

There are to versions you can choose depending on your printer resolution.

title: Modern Jet Turbine Fan Fidget Spinner

description.text:
This is the modern version of my other Jet Turbine Fan Fidget Spinner.

I designed this to resemble todays' "Fan" section of a jet turbine engine. Simply blowing on it will spin it.

The fan is directional. Due to the curve of the blades, blowing on it from one side vs the other will make it spin much faster. Just holding it to the air vent in your car with the blower on high will spin it a lot.

The arrows show the direction of air flow for optimal rotational velocity.

Requires 1, 608 (22mm) bearing.

Please post your comments and makes!

Try this spinner on my pinwheel stick! https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2350624

Use my Spinner Press to help insert the bearing and center caps. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2275122

Printer:

Hatchbox Alpha

No

No

Resolution:

.20mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

No rafts or supports needed.

It took 59 minutes to print on my printer using the above settings. I print at 195C with a bed temp of 60.

title: LED strip mount for Robo R2 printer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Was getting tired of not seeing anything in my R2 (stock lighting if we can call it that is utterly useless), so I installed 2x 12-LED long pieces of strip on top.
This mount follows the curve of the printer and gives a 40° downwards angle to the LEDs. The strip can be stuck right on, and use double sided foam tape to stick to the printer.

Both pieces of 12V strip are wired in series and connected to the 24V power input behind the power switch (first 2 pins of the green connector, see photo).

Print with a temperature-resistant filament, PLA will warp after a while of being exposed to heat from the printer bed.

author: borderjs

description.text: Inside the PhonoHorn is a circuit that plays a certain melody. The enclosure amplifies the sound.

The four 'orders' are:
DORIC - the simplest of the Greek orders.
TUSCAN - the Roman version of Doric.
IONIC - with large 'volutes' (scrolls) on the capital.
CORINTHIAN - the most ornate capital with curving acanthus leaves.

All the columns are designed with correct 'entasis', (the gentle convex curve along the shaft,) and the name of each order is embossed into the base of each column.

The DORIC column is 14cm. tall and is printed in one piece, upside-down. Printing time is 2hr 4min.
The TUSCAN column is 14cm. tall. The shaft and capital are printed separately. Printing times are: Shaft - 1hr 47min. Capital - 16min.
The IONIC column is 14.3cm. tall. The shaft and capital are printed separately, and the capital is printed in two halves on their sides. Printing times are: Shaft - 2hr. Capital (two halves printed together) - 30min.
The CORINTHIAN column is 14.8cm. tall. The shaft and capital are printed separately, and the capital is printed in two halves on their sides. Printing times are: Shaft - 2hr 2min. Capital (two halves printed together) - 31min.

The shafts (apart from the Doric which is printed in one piece,) have a peg at the top which fits into a slot in the capital. Capitals and shafts can then be permanently fixed together with a few dabs of superglue. (I use Lepage's 'Ultra Gel') The times given are those taken by my Makerbot (Fifth Generation) printer.

title: iPad Pro Cup Holder for Ford Expedition

description.text:
This is a iPad Pro Cup Holder to place my iPad Pro in the middle console of the a Ford Expedition and play movies and have the sound come out thru the car stereo system.
There is 2 different designs, one requires 2 cup holders and the other one requires only one cup holder.
There is 3 different STL files that allows you to print either one.
The cup holders fit the expedition without the rubber inserts, but you can use the rubber inserts for cup holders too… it just will sit higher.
I printed the one that requires both cup holders mainly because I wanted the iPad to be centered, but you can use only one if that is what you prefer.
I used 8% fill and I printed supports and a raft.

This is a pill box containing 8 slots (one which is left open so that the other 7 are sealed). The eighth slot has two indentations either side of it into which nubs on the lid slot. This means (or should mean) that the pills don't all fall out when this is in your bag.
The lid has a gap in it, originally I had planned to put indented text in the edge of the base but I couldn't work it out in SketchUp so I ditched it, however you could now write the days with permanent marker into the gaps this would leave open so you still know, provided you printed it in white ABS or similar. This was inspired by thing 3938 so I'll make this a derivative, however that design required some hardware and I thought I could come up with something totally printable given the flexibility of ABS in some circumstances. I've not printed this so anyone willing to give it a go would be welcomed! :D
Also, it's 80mm in diameter by 26mm deep including the lid.

Print off one of each file, a lid and a base.
Squeeze the two prongs on the lid together before inserting them into the hole in the base.
Push straight down until it clips into place.
Fill with your chosen medications.
Medicate yourself for a week, remembering to turn the lid back round to it's locked 'Day 0' position so you don't lose all of your pills while you aren't looking.
Rinse and repeat from the filling up part.

comments.text:
@MKSA I concur, it is a good design in theory but there is no end bearing and uses screws for shafts. So would not last very long even if it did work.
I printed one just to prove that it did not work. If you put an end bearing on it is almost usable. But the gears are so thin that they cannot take any lateral force without jinking and seizing the entire mechanism and the stepper.
I think it might be possible to get around these problems, at least partially, and will update you with progress if I have any! Including parametric files and videos of it working if that ever happens.
This design is not usable for it's stated purpose as an extruder but could still be used as a simple in line reducer gear. In fact with no lateral force on the output shaft it works perfectly.
Thanks to Trigubovich for posting it, it has inspired me. But perhaps you should mark it as a work in progress until you can show it working as an extruder.

description.text:
Update[27.7.2017] Release version, obsolete versions removed, Fusion 360 links added:
-Trispinner http://a360.co/2vMkWzz
-Dualspinner http://a360.co/2h5THwv
-buttons http://a360.co/2h5YQoy

You can spin just gears, or you can spin whole thing and gears will spin with it. Bearing hole tolerance is +0.2mm, don't expect long spin times, especially if you're using low quality gears.Blue one in photo with discarded Chinese gears spins 30 seconds, and gears spin for 10 seconds.

If people are interested I'll clean and release Fusion 360 file, meanwhile, if you want different bearing holes, or bevel-spur version feel free to ask, I'll make and release it.

-all 608 bearing is impossible
-I tried to utilize airsoft bearings as bearings instead of spacers, they have much higher friction than 608 or 606.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 3

Resolution:

doesn't matter

Infill:

30% is enough, probably can go lower

Notes:

For body 20% infill is enough, to ensure buttons' durability print them 100% infil, or at least set wall thickness to 1.5mm or higher.

The blue one in photos was printed on Ultimaker 2+ normal settings 20% infil 1mm wall thickness normal quality, except layer height 0.15mm with Ultimaker blue PLA
push airsoft bearings into fidget bearing, push bearing into holes shim like usual, or just push them closer.

2x 606 bearing
2x 6mm airsoft bushing, you may need glue to kill it(or you can try it with "longer button") I suggest to use longer on one side and short one with 6mm bearing/bushing on other. That way you won't need any glue Dual version:
, 4x 608 bearings, 4x 8mm airsoft bearings/bushings, V2/V3 2x spur gears and 1x sector gear OR 2xsector and one spur (see photo). I highly suggest to use identical or at least as similar as possible. Tri version:
6x 608 bearings, 6x 8mm airsoft bearings/bushings, V2/V3 3x spur gears and 1x sector gear OR 3xsector and one spur (see photo). I highly suggest to use identical or at least as similar as possible.

description.text:
UPDATED 9/20/17

  • Added two new models. Fang Coolers for the Titan Aero Extruder! As I don't have an Aero myself, they may not be perfect, so please give any feedback you can. Thanks and enjoy

To Do Still

  • Widen the nozzle ends without completely breaking the model.

After installing a RJ45 upgrade to my FT-5 I was left without a part cooling fan. I really like the style of the "Fang" coolers but have yet to find one that fit the stock FT-5 hot end, so I came up with these solutions. There are files for both a 5015 Radial fan (two different mount options), and a 40x40mm axial fan.

All versions of this fan duct are very much a work in progress still, so any feedback you have would be greatly appreciated!

Printer:

Folgertech FT-5

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I opted to include a raft to help with first layer adhesion, and set custom supports through S3D. Other programs supports should work well though.

I will probably end up changing the fan shroud design for easier printing at some point.

Print upside down for best results!
When you are ready to install the fan duct, you will have to use two M3x45mm screws to reassemble the hot end fan assembly as the 40mm bolts are two short with the added thickness of the fan shroud.

remixed_from.title: Quickfit Greg's Wade reloaded extruder body - jonaskuehling variant - For Buddaschnozzle

description.text:
This MPCNC add on allows you to make your own motion controlled videos with your MPCPC.

In addition, you'll need to print a set up herringbone Gears like https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:97377

You will also need a stepper motor. I used a Short Body Nema 17 Bipolar Step Motor from Amazon.com. But a full body may fit too, with a slightly longer M8 screw.

You'll need an M8 screw, and bearings/washers for the extruder body. You don't need a large-head extruder bolt, just use the standard head adapter part included with this thingy.

If you wish you can secure the small herringbone screw with a setscrew, but I didn't. The fit is tight and the load is very small, so friction fit should be enough.

Use in conjunction with the MPCNC Motion Controller Software at www.someoldguycoding/software

title: Runcam Split camera holder for QAV 180 / 210

description.text:
This camera holder is for the Runcam Split camera (may also work with other cameras of the same profile), and should work for both a QAV 180 and 210 frame. The mounting hardware that came with the Runcam Split didn't work very well, so I designed this one. This design brings the camera forward a little bit. This is intended to be printed with a semi-flex filament. I used Sainsmart TPU and it works great. Anything softer (eg NinjaFlex) will probably not support the camera as well, and anything harder (eg PLA) may cause too much jello.

When using your camera with the holder, you will still see some of the standoffs in the video if you fly at a steep angle. I am thinking about doing another version that moves the camera out past the standoffs so this will no longer be a problem (down side is the lens won't be protected).

You'll need to use one of the small included screws (that comes the Runcam Split) in the bottom holes of the camera.

Sample video footage here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0MF9jcGSdZQ

Printer:

Reach 3d

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Use a semi-flex filament.

description.text:
This is a holder optimized for Anycubic Kossel Linear Plus.

Mainboard in this printer is difficult to install and hold, there is a little space between bars and the most of it stay on air and move in annoying way.

This is a simply model to hold it.

I used M3 screw to set it to mainboard and M4 to pin up to structure and for the bar.

I designed and printed it with big square, but when i installed it i saw that wasn´t necessary at all and cut it, V2 is enough.

Anycubic Kossel Plus

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10/100

Notes:

100% infill for bars and 10% for square.

I used support for holes.

remixed_from.title: Mosaic simple side mounted cooling fan

description.text: This is a slight modification of elmoray's MakerGear Mosaic simple side mounted cooling fan. I sliced off a corner or two and rotated it, so it should be a bit nicer to print. The print in the images was done from Ultimachine's natural ABS ( http://ultimachine.com/content/abs-175mm-natural-1kg-spool ) with 0.2mm layer height and no support. I've included the OpenSCAD file as well as elmoray's original 'Simple Side Mount.stl' which it imports.
Download "mosaic_side_fan.stl", slice, print and install as in the picture. I used 3 M3x20mm cap screws with nylock nuts.

description.text:
This is a pop filter and mount designed for ATR2100 XLR/USB microphones, or any similar microphone with a 30mm barrel. The pop filter connects to the bracket with a piece of 2mm music wire, available at hardware stores, bent to shape.

You'll also need M3 screws and nuts to affix the mount to the barrel of the microphone. I used button cap screws which just fit into the pockets of the top of the bracket, and stop nuts.

This isn't an original design, but a version of a product I saw elsewhere.

Printer:

Anet A8

Notes:

Print 'ATR 2100 mesh.stl' without solid top and bottom layers and a 35% infill (UPDATE: 35% isn't enough to eliminate pops. Try some higher values). I used Cura's triangle infill pattern.

Note: the tubular section of the mesh (where the wire is inserted) printed fine, but broke off later. Nevertheless there was plenty of room left to insert the wire.

Battare

This is a low poly model of the CN Tower in Edmonton, a landmark Modern building completed in 1966.

The STL was converted from a great Sketchup Model created by newfangled, and the original can be found here: https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model/cc1968cac9089cd533a337b6b838f975/CN-Tower

Netfabb Basic was used to repair the model automagically and some manual triangle faces were also flipped into the correct orientation. A more skillful 3D designer may be able to add some of the detail back.

The building has been scaled to roughly 1:400, but still may need further scaling.

More info on the building can be found here: http://capitalmodernedmonton.com/buildings-by-area/downtown/cntower/

Photograph by James Dow.

A simple holder for four pliers.

This is a waterbottle-sized heli/mono/uni-copter designed to hover in the air at the spot it's first deployed. As opposed to vectoring the propellers to provide directional motion, the center of mass located in the pendulum is shifted instead.

See the assembly better here: http://a360.co/2um5yMn

This build requires:
1x Arduino Nano
1x Bluetooth Module
1x Accelerometer/gyroscope Module
2x Micro Servos
2x ESC (Motor Controller)
1x 1000Kv contra-rotating motor assembly
1x Li-Po Battery
Your favorite semi-permanent adhesive
A few other 3D printed components.
Designed in Autodesk Fusion 360 with assets from GrabCAD.com

comments.text: The integration of servos, and using pendulum mass for movement are the only parts that require this to be a large (water bottle size) build. it could end up much smaller, if you ignore movement entirely(though this does leave it susceptible to wind drift)

title: Dactyl extended bottom case with gel wrist rests

description.text:
Extended case bottom for Dactyl keyboard (designed by Matt Aderath). This bottom case is compatible with the standard Dactyl top case/plate. It allows for expanded building room on the inside, and free Teensy (or other pcb) placement, with a plate mounted USB extender. I used the following for a full infinity style build. This case also supports a 4th screw, which has no effect on a normal Dactyl top plate. You can go down to 1x of the USB parts if you are doing a normal IO expander build.

Extra STLsStandalone wrist rest for normal style dactyls included in files.

Like solar powered things? Like swinging things? Like whales? Like solar powered swinging whales? Well if you answered yes to all of the previous questions, then the Solar Power Swinging Whale is for you. Video of prototype at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nHj41gYe0D4. You'll need to purchase one of those solar powered hula girls, snowman, devil, etc. (I used the devil) found at the dollar store (for a dollar), or on the web. You'll also need a 12mm by 3mm magnet, and some sewing thread. Designed using Sketchup 8, and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" settings except for "Whale.stl", which was printed with 0% infill.

Study "Assembly.skp" before proceeding (it can be viewed with the free version of Sketchup 8).  
Carefully remove the base from the solar powered devil (or hula girl, snowman, etc.).  Once removed, I placed a dot of cyanoacrylate glue on each end of the solar panel to hold it in place.  
Print "Base.stl", and fit it over the solar powered base, such that the solar panel tower protrudes through the rectangle in "Base.stl".  
Print "Riser.stl".  
Print "Solar Cover.stl".  Slide "Riser.stl" into slot in "Solar Cover.stl".  
Slide the "Solar Cover.stl" and "Riser.stl" assembly over the solar panel tower.  
Print "Whale.stl".  
Press the magnet between the fins of "Whale.stl", just enough to hold it in place.  
Run thread from "Riser.stl", through the eyelet on top of "Whale.stl", then back to "Riser.stl".  Adjust the length of the thread such that the magnet is 1 to 2mm above the top surface of "Base.stl" and nothing drags.  
Turn on the lights and watch it swing.

The new Eachine Wizard 220S is just out. The carbon fiber side covers tend to pinch the wires. I fly with a Spektrum radio using a Lemon RC receiver. This set of sides will not fit the standard Wizard 220.

title: Tom Mason Specification Miniature Sculpting Stand

description.text:
Based on Tom Mason's wooden sculpting stand:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o2l9c0RSK40&lc=z12atptieqywt1axa04ceptyqongtrgrcbk.1498620926869977

I designed this to accept a #10 x 1" long screw, washer, and nut. Now, this could be used with equivalent metric fasteners (not tested as such however). The hole for screw is 3mm in diameter. The hexagon is 12mm (if we draw a circle around the hexagon, inscribed within a circle hexagon in AutoCAD terms), or 10.39mm across the flats. The pocket for the washer is 14mm across, again, with the 3mm through hole for the #10 machine screw. You could use a metric M3, though you might need to drill it out a bit, or accept that the threads are going to dig into the plastic.

My 3D print warped a bit, and does not offer a flat surface on the inside. Go figure, my settings are still off! Mainly, my bed doesn't have PEI anymore, just masking tape. That and I used ABS. I should get some PLA and see what happens!

title: Dummy NEMA 17 motor (shaft mount)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I decided to change my Prusa I3 clone to use only 1 Z-motor, driving the other leadscrew with a belt, so needed to remove the one motor. I designed this dummy motor to fit in its place.

It uses two 5 x 14 x 5 mm bearings and a 5mm shaft of about 100mm long for a dual shaft NEMA equivalent.

Also required are 4 x M3 nuts and longer M3 mounting screws.

I have supplied two top bearing retainers of different thicknesses. These change the overall length of the 'motor', which has a nominal length of 48mm.

Other parts designed for my printers include:

comments.text: Can you post a picture of the final setup? I'm trying to work out how to run this.
comments.author: RGN01

comments.text: It is very difficult to photograph because of the layout - the continuous belt is under the Y - carriage. My setup is very simple. Replaced left Z stepper with double ended one. Added pulley to lower shaft of motor. Removed right hand stepper and replaced with this (as shown in first photo). Linked the two with a continuous belt, with tensioner. Adjusted Z heights and tightened belt. Job done and not had to worry about the two Z-heights getting out of sync again.

Download an STL or hack the OpenSCAD to get an arm any way you want it.  Print 4 and combine with the rest of the PL2Q project.
UPDATE: The new 1 piece arm STL has 11 sides and a proper inner diameter of 13 mm.  This should print well and fit nicely on PL2Q motor mounts.
UPDATE 2: The 2 pieces are not the same length as the original.  Where they slide together, that length is lost.  I bet it's still a good length for flying, but I have no exp.
UPDATE 3: Added a 2 piece arm STL file where they fit together to create the same height as the original Hugin arm.  Also updated the SCAD file.
It's probably best to print with 3 shells.
I did not think this was a "work in progress", but anything lower than 11 sides on the arm and a circular inside (to mate with the motor mount) causes some extremely thin spots and the part might wobble when being print horizontally.
If you print the 2 piece vertical version and they don't fit together nicely, boil some water, let it sit and cool down some, dip the ends of the parts into the water and fit them together while still wet.  Works for PLA because the glass transition temp is 60c, not sure about ABS.

I created 3D figures to help students understand the definition of volume. Students will fill the figures with mini M&Ms and count how many they can fit in each figure representing the definition of volume.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

Yes

No

standard

10%
I used tinkercad to create 3D figures. For each figure, I created a hole in the center that was smaller than the figure itself.
CCSS

The lesson before this one introduced volume to students. They were given all of the volume formulas and were able to practice one of each. This lesson will give students a better understanding of the definition of volume and how to apply it. It also gives students a chance to practice calculating the volume of different 3D figures.

Instructions: Find a partner. I will give each partnership five figures. The five figures are a cube, cylinder, rectangular prism, pyramid and a cone. Yesterday we learned the formulas for volumes. We are going to find the volume of each of the figures by counting how many mini M&Ms will fit in each. Then we will use the formulas we learned yesterday to calculate the volume to check. 
Do Now: With your partner, make a prediction of the order of the figures from smallest volume to largest volume and record in the boxes below. 
Part I: Count the amount of mini M&Ms that fit in each figure. 
Part II: Calculate the volume. 
Part III: Conclusion Questions.
Each partnership needs the five figures, mini M&Ms and a calculator.

• Definition of Volume
  • Volume Application
  • Calculations
One 40 minute period
Need all of the 3D figures printed before class and have enough mini M&Ms.
Students were not graded. At the end of the lesson, I made a chart on the board and students came up to show their answers.

Because my printer does not print well if it does not have something to print a base layer for say the arms on so it prints the first arm layer on the support stucture. remixed_from.author: DrLex
remixed_from.title: FlashForge Creator Pro front dual fan duct

title: FlashForge Creator Pro left single extruder fan duct

description.text:
This is the single-extrusion alternative to my dual duct. I only do a dual extrusion about once every 100 prints, and I figured it is a bit pointless to have the dual duct blow air at the inactive (and usually unscrewed) nozzle all the time. It makes more sense to also direct this air at the active nozzle. By blowing air from two directions, this design reduces the ‘shadow’ problem of both the stock duct and my dual duct, and cools all sides more or less equally. If you're only going to print with one extruder, this duct will give you the best quality.
Of course this does not make the dual duct obsolete: you still need it to get proper cooling on dual extrusions.

Mind that the shadow problem is not completely eliminated. Overhangs at the rear and right will still be cooled less effectively because the air cannot reach their undersides. One way to work around this, is to print extra structures behind such overhangs, to reflect the airflow back towards them. In most cases this will be unnecessary however, but keep it in mind for those prints that need to be really perfect.

This duct has not been merely designed in a wet-finger guessing way. It has been run through several dozens of iterations, the last of which were validated with computer simulations. See the ‘How I Designed This’ section for more details.

This duct unfortunately is not plug-and-play. You must read the ‘Using’ section. If you don't, your prints will fail, you have been warned.

The photos show a comparison of my 55° mushroom test on a PLA print between this duct, the v6 dual duct, and the stock duct. The result from the stock duct looks more decent than what I expected while I saw it being printed: it was curling up so badly at times that I feared I would need to abort the print. Somehow the upper layers managed to push down the curls again, but it still looks ugly. Even despite the fact that I did this test with the first version of the new duct which was not anywhere as good as the latest version, the result shows almost no deformations and it has a near-flat top surface. (Note: you won't be able to get this kind of result on the 55° test with the stock nozzles, especially not if they have been worn out. This was printed with a more pointy Micro Swiss hardened steel nozzle, which allows to print steeper overhangs than a nozzle with a flat underside.)
 

Printing
There are two models. The ‘x1’ model has the exhausts 1 mm lower than the regular model. If you aligned your nozzles with this tool, you need the regular version. If you installed Micro Swiss all-metal hotends and followed their installation instructions to the letter, then your nozzles will be 1 mm lower and you need the ‘x1’ model. See the section ‘Checking the height of your nozzle’ below for more details. Or, you can just print both models and see which one works best for you.

See the Print Settings section for detailed instructions on printing.
 

Installing
Be sure to read the Post-Printing section first.

A thin strip of rubber (like a piece of bicycle tire) under the little mounting tab can help to avoid that the duct vibrates and rattles.

If you have an older printer and yet have to install the blower fan, you may need to print the fan mounting bracket first.
 

Using
First of all, if you're going to do a long print with the fan disabled entirely, remove the duct to avoid that it will deform, especially if you're printing at very high temperatures, e.g. polycarbonate. Even if you applied thermal insulation, you should still remove the duct if unused during long prints.

Next, something very important: don't just print and try to use this duct, it unfortunately is not that simple. This duct is almost unusable if you cannot control fan speed. You would get very poor layer adhesion in the lower part of your print, and fast-printed parts like infill may detach already during printing. In other words, your print will fall apart. To avoid this, you must reduce fan speed in a specific manner. Unfortunately fan speed cannot be controlled on an unmodified FFCP, which I find the largest shortcoming of this printer by far. The only practical way to adjust fan speed, is to install a PWM controller of some kind in between the printer motherboard and the cooling fan.

Due to effects described below (see ‘Background info’ if you're interested), you must:

  • only enable the fan after the second or third layer,
  • start out with the fan running at no more than 20% speed,
  • gradually increase fan speed over the course of the first 12 mm of the print until the desired maximum (in many cases, 50% is more than enough).

Your software might make it seem as if you can vary the speed of the fan, but this is a lie. All printers that use the MightyBoard design like the FFCP and clones, cannot control fan speed. The MightyBoard can only toggle its EXTRA output between off and on, hence ramping up the fan won't be possible unless you make modifications. You could act as a human PWM controller by manually toggling the fan on and off using the LCD menu to gradually speed it up, but this is extremely cumbersome.

There are some alternative workarounds you could try, but being able to control fan speed is by far the best solution. It is also essential for getting good results with filaments like PETG, which require a tiny bit of cooling for best results. You may also be surprised to hear that I always enable the fan on ABS prints, albeit at a low speed, which does improve quality without ruining layer adhesion. Also, after installing an all-metal hot-end with hardened steel nozzle, I noticed I need much less cooling, which made it essential to be able to throttle the fan.

The best solution at the moment is therefore a hardware PWM controller. Here is an example with some instructions how to install one. It isn't that complicated, and the only permanent modification you need to make to your printer, is to drill two tiny holes. You can use an analog controller like the one shown there, or a microcontroller like an Arduino with PWM capable output. A microcontroller could automate some of the control, like the gradual speed-up.

It is possible to install a custom build of the Sailfish firmware that has a software PWM implementation. However, the speed cannot be changed during a print, and it does not respond to speed arguments in the G-code, making it mostly useless until someone finally implements that feature.

Possible workarounds that do not require a PWM controller
Simplest one is to just stick with the dual duct, if you find it too much hassle to get the best out of this single-extruder duct. You will of course be stuck with the shadow problem too.

Or, if you print much hotter, slowly, and in thin layers, you might get good results even if you cannot throttle the fan.

To counteract the typical extruder temperature undershoot when the fan activates at lower layers, you could boost extruder temperature by 10°C, about 10 seconds before the fan will engage. I haven't tested whether this is effective, but in theory it should ensure the extruder is in its heating regime when the blast of cold air hits it, and the undershoot should be reduced or eliminated. You may then gradually reduce extruder temperature again until the print is about 12 mm tall, but you should keep the temperature higher than when printing without fan. This is obviously cumbersome, because you will either have to manually fiddle with the LCD menu to do this, or write a post-processing script to insert extra M104 commands in your G-code at the right places.

You may also try to make a hole in the side of the duct to lower the exhaust pressure. You could use tape to vary the size of this hole, to vary airflow in a clumsy manner. Of course, this doesn't avoid the undershoot problem, and trying to vary the airflow during a print will be challenging to say the least.

Background info: why is throttling the fan necessary?
There are two things at play here. First, the PID controller implementation in the Sailfish firmware is very bad at reacting to temperature drops. The reaction is way too slow, therefore if something causes the extruder temperature to suddenly drop, there will be a severe temperature undershoot, and part of the print will be printed too cold; layer adhesion will be compromised.

Second, during the first layers of the print, both the extruder and the duct are very close to the bed. This causes the air to ‘bounce’, forcing it between the bed and heater block, greatly increasing overall airflow. The air hitting the heater block causes the extruder to lose heat, which triggers the PID undershoot problem. Moreover, even if the undershoot would not occur, the material would still get cooled much harder than expected. All ducts suffer from this problem, which is why many poorly designed ducts (like the stock duct) work decently during the lower part of the print, and do nearly nothing higher up. My duct is designed to work well at all times, which unfortunately causes it to work too well during the lower layers…

Therefore, the fan must be started slowly during the lower layers to avoid the undershoot. Its speed must also be kept lower than usual during approximately the lower 12 mm of the print, because that's the region where the ‘bounce’ effect remains significant.

Isn't there an automated way to throttle the fan like this?
Unfortunately, not that I know of. Having to manually turn a PWM controller knob is indeed annoying, especially on big prints. The Cura slicer program does offer the required gradual ramp-up feature, and it could be easily added with a simple post-processing script for other slicers. As explained above however, the FFCP as-is has no way to vary fan speed. The fan is connected to the ‘EXTRA’ output on the MightyBoard, which is a simple toggle with no PWM capabilities.

When looking at the optional PWM emulation in Sailfish, it seems it could be extended to also respond to speed arguments in X3G files. This would be good, because then we could control the fan from within G-code as on many other printers. I am however not aware of a Sailfish build with this feature. If someone does, I would like to hear about it! It isn't the best possible solution however, because slicer programs, as well as the GPX conversion program that turns G-code into X3G files, currently drop fan speed arguments because they are aware of the MightyBoard's limitations, therefore those programs would also need to be hacked.

In my opinion, the best solution would be to use an Arduino or Raspberry Pi as PWM controller, and send instructions to this controller from within the G-code, through some serial connection. This would offer the best of two worlds: automatic control with possibility of manual override without interfering with the print. The controller can also take care of ‘kickstarting’ the fan at low speeds. The hardest part is to find a way to send data to an external device from within the G-code. I have found only one solution so far, but it is so crazy that I won't tell what it is until I have a working proof-of-concept.
 

Final Notes
If you want to be notified of possible updates on this design, use the ‘Watch’ button.

Quite a bit of work went into designing this duct. If you appreciate it, remember that there is a ‘tip designer’ button :)

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

As with the dual duct, or any duct whatsoever, you must print this in a heat-resistant material because it is very close to the heater block, moreover this duct has even more material near the heated bed. Do not print it in PLA. I recommend ABS, although even that is not sufficiently heat-resistant on its own during ABS or PETG prints. If you are able to print in polycarbonate, it is probably the best option if you often print with the bed above 100°C or the extruders at 230°C or more. However, an ABS printed duct will do fine if you add extra insulation (see post-printing section).

Same comments as for the dual duct: do not enable supports. Supports will block the inner passages, and the model is designed such that it will print well without supports. I recommend enabling cooling while printing the top layer of the main vent and the upper tip of the left exhaust (for this purpose the stock duct should suffice).
Infill doesn't matter much if your slicer is configured to always print small areas solid. If unsure, set infill to 100% for the entire print.

Preparing the duct for mounting

You should clear the little hole next to the mounting screw hole with a 2 mm drill bit. Otherwise you'll probably have a hard time mounting the duct onto the carriage.

Protecting the duct against heat

Even if you printed the duct in ABS, it still is very close to the heater block, and the exhausts will deform if the duct is exposed to high temperatures for more than just a few minutes. If the exhausts deform, the duct will no longer work optimally. You should therefore consider applying some thermal insulation to the exhausts.
If you're only going to print PLA or other filaments that do not require extruder temperatures above 210°C, and if you're going to enable the fan all the time, you might be able to use the duct uninsulated because it will keep itself cooled. However, you still risk damaging the duct when printing something large, because the fan will only be enabled after the first few layers (at least, it should). If you're going to print ABS or PETG, you definitely must insulate the duct.

As shown in the photos, I use some NASA-style insulation that consists of a layer of self-adhesive aluminium foil, with a layer of kapton tape on top. To be really sure, I applied this twice at the tips of the exhausts. It is time-consuming to apply this, but it is well worth it because it has proven to be extremely effective. However, if you have only one of those materials, I believe a few layers of just aluminium or just kapton will also do the trick.

Lunar lander inspired insulation!

SimScale / OpenFOAM

I considered simulating the duct in OpenFOAM, but its learning curve is a bit too steep for something I will only be using once or twice. Therefore I first tried the same trial-and-error methods as for the dual duct. These however proved ineffective: the two interacting airflows made the windmill unusable; blowing onto a water surface or a layer of dry sand, was also pointless because these methods constrain the test to a 2D surface. (By the way, be extremely careful if you would ever cover the glass bed in your printer with sand. Due to static charge build-up, the sand is likely to jump upwards at the moment you remove the glass plate. It is a very cool physics demonstration, but getting the sand out of all the nooks and crannies of your printer is not very cool.)

In the end I did simulate the duct, using SimScale which offers a web interface on top of OpenFOAM for CFD simulations, so this eliminates most of the learning curve. Moreover, it is entirely free for public community projects (with a simulation time budget of 3000 hours). You can find the public project here.
I ended up performing some 15 different simulations. I couldn't imagine printing and manually testing all those prototypes, so the simulations proved invaluable. I did have some problems getting the STL model to work, but in the end I found out how to properly do it, and I can conclude that SimScale is really great.

Airflow velocity around the tip of the nozzle. It is impossible to get a perfectly uniform flow field with only two exhausts, but this is about the best I could get within the constraints of this design. Flow in the exhausts. Getting this well-balanced was not trivial. Flow cross-section of the right exhaust. For the left exhaust, see the Thing photo gallery.

description.header: Checking the height of your nozzle
description.text: If you're unsure whether you need the regular or x1 model, you can verify this as follows. Bring the carriage forward so it is flush with the front edge of the print bed. Then raise the bed until it just touches the nozzle, as shown in the photo. Next, measure the distance between the bed and the bottom of the carriage. If this is close to 10 mm, you need the regular model. If it is closer to 11 mm, you need the x1 model.

description.header: Will there be a version of this duct for the right extruder?
description.text:
No.

Reasons:

  1. The left nozzle is closest to the fan, making it much easier to design a duct with two exhausts blowing at it. I don't see any practical way to make a similar configuration for the right nozzle, not even if the left heater block would be removed. The second exhaust would need to make a wide curve around the back, making it large, heavy, and very difficult to print.
  2. If you mostly print with one extruder and want to remove the heavy unused stepper motor to reduce ringing artifacts on single-nozzle extrusions, it is way easier to remove and reinstall the right stepper. (You do need to put something in place to trigger the X endstop.)

2017/07/26: v2

I noticed that the first version blew way too much air forward. I did most of my tests with the duct in free air, and neglected the fact that when mounted, the airflow would be inclined to get sucked against nearby structures. This did happen and it caused the heater and nozzle to struggle to maintain their temperature. This version improves upon this with a funky new exhaust design, and should also better aim its airflow in the horizontal plane.

Small update 2017/08/05: v2b
This is the same design but with a few minor changes that should make it slightly more robust, and also easier to mount with less risk of it cracking.

2017/10/21: v3

Almost a complete redesign, the result of performing CFD simulations in SimScale (OpenFOAM). The flows have been balanced and the dead zones have been eliminated. This duct is pretty much guaranteed to be very good. A nice side effect of the optimizations is that the duct is smaller and easier to mount.

comments.text:
Hello doc!
Do you know of a power supply i can use to power my fan that is controlled by the program code.
So i can switch the nozzle fan on after say 4 layers.
I have the flashforge creator pro.
Thank you
comments.author: Red_duke

comments.text:
Normally you would just connect the fan to the EXTRA output on the motherboard, as is the case on the 2016 model, no separate power supply is needed. This output is the one that is switched on/off by M126/M127 commands in the G-code. It can deliver more than enough current to drive the fan. Be aware that it delivers 24V, so if you yet have to buy a fan, make sure it is a 24V one.
If you have yet to install the fan and wiring anyhow, make sure to connect a PWM controller in between, so you can throttle the speed, otherwise it will simply ruin your prints as explained in the description.

comments.text: The new version is ready and confirmed to be good, so I added the .blend file. Mind that you should avoid making changes to the airflow path unless you know what you're doing.
comments.author: joshhenry

comments.text:
This was designed in Blender, which is mesh-oriented, not volume-oriented like STEP. I'll make the file available when I'm content with the design, which is currently not the case yet.
I have noticed the airflow is uneven between the two exhausts, and the flow of the left exhaust does not end up where I want it to. I have improved the first problem, but aiming the air is far more difficult than with the dual duct, because the two flows interact. I have done some tests with sand on the build plate, but this gives a false result because it is constrained to 2D. I'm planning to use a simulator to put an end to my trial-and-error method and ever increasing pile of experimental prints.
If you really want, I can already give you the current design, but if you can wait a few more weeks, I hope to have something better.
comments.author: joshhenry

comments.text: Is there any chance that you could make this in the RIGHT Extruder version? I almost always use just the right one. You have an awesome idea there and I have been using version 5,6 as they were being released. Been using those since December. Thanks in advance if you would consider making that.
comments.author: wavapps

comments.text:
No, sorry. It is way more difficult to design something like this for the right extruder, and even if I would manage to do it, it would be large and curvy and very difficult to print. It would become slightly more feasible if the left heater block would be removed, but you wouldn't want to do that routinely. Even then, the exhaust needs to curve around the heater block, making it nearly unprintable. It would also be continuously baked by the heater and risk deforming.
Why don't you use the left extruder?
comments.author: wavapps

comments.text: Well I use PETG only, and I have the printer set up for the right extruder for black and the left extruder for blue. I actually have 2 PowerSpec 3DPro32 Printers set up this way. They are a clone of the FlashForge Creator Pro.

I printed it threads facing the printing plate with supports on.

http://thousandoaksoptical.com/shop/solar-filters/silver-black-polymer-sheets/

If anyone knows how to create 58x0.75 threads in F360, please let me know.

title: Nano Skyhunter - APM Mini GPS Mounting Tray
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix of Zapf's mounting tray for the Nano Skyhunter. It has been lengthened by 2mm and new mounting holes (32.5mm x 32.5mm center to center) have been created to allow mounting a APM mini GPS that uses the same mounting hole pattern.

I printed mine with 4 bottom and 4 top solid layers, 0.100 layer height, 10% infill and 2 perimeters.

Instructions:
1) Attach standoffs to the holes in the mount
2) Attached your flight controller or GPS to the standoffs
3) Slide out the existing wood tray from the Nano Skyhunter
4) Place the mount in at a slight angle press into the slots in the foam
5) Slide tray backwards into final position

title: Maker Select Exotic Dancer Filament Guide

description.text:
Tired of your boring filament guide? Install this exotic dancer and watch her swing and guide your filament haha! To assemble insert a 35mm piece of 4mm bowden tube and secure with a drop of super glue if needed. Be sure you sand or file the ball until she moves effortlessly. Attach dancer to base and clip on where needed. Make sure you leave a comment and/or a make. Enjoy!

UPDATE 7/23/17
I added 2 new bases remixed from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2029321. I found the original base to be too light. I recommend 50% infill for the bases to give them more weight. Also changed recommended bowden tube size from 45mm to 35mm. She's much more secure now.

UPDATE 8/20/17
Added a new dancer that doesn't require bowden tube. She has an incorporated tube with a 3mm inside diameter.

title: Orca v4.x Modified extruder base for feeding Eco Flex PLA

description.text:
When I started to use Eco Flex PLA, it would not feed through the Orca.
Due to its flexibility, it would immediately bend and loop outside the extruder base.
I diagnosed more support was needed on the way down into the hot-end.
This is a modified base, that gives additional support after passing the idler.
Currently it is on the printer... hope it fits and does the thing :-)

description.text: A simple cube puzzle based on a child's posting box. Eight small cubes are to be assembled into a larger cube. The small cubes are connected by square, cylindrical, or triangular holes and extrusions. The problem is presented in two forms, one where the large cube has smooth sides, a second where the large cube is decorated with additional holes. Both have the same solutions; the second version may be more difficult. OpenSCAD code is included.

The included pdf image was generated by an openSCAD program. It shows the puzzle design and can be used as an aid to the solution of the puzzles. There are however multiple answers and an answer may not exactly correspond to the diagram.

Each puzzle is made of 8 pieces, all different. A preliminary version of the puzzle was composed of 8 identical pieces. A piece from this preliminary puzzle is present in one of the final puzzles. Finding it can serve as an additional problem. See the openSCAD code.
