title: Gear Cover For Traxxas 2wd RC vehicles 32p Gears

description.text:
there has always been an issue since someone going from a 48 pitch to a 32-pitch gears and their Traxxas 2-wheel RC vehicles because there is no gear cover design to address this issue until now. I would like to take all of the credit for this design but I cannot take all of the credit for this. I got this cad file from someone that goes by the username of DavidCalado as I was looking on thingiverse I discovered this two-wheel conversion that he did and one of his files contains this gear cover and I saw one of his photos of this gear cover installed on his two wheel slash that he converted into a buggy. So I like what I saw so I downloaded his files and I retrieve one of his files that contain the gear cover the only thing I did with his cad file is did a slight modification by extending it to make some more room for the purpose of allowing this redesign gear cover that i have redesign To accommodate the 32 pitch spur gears that some people are doing with their Traxxas 2-wheel vehicles. If you wish to download this file you will need the traxxas stock gear cover part number: 3792 and get the Rubber Plug that came with your RC vehicle or buy one and the photo should give you an idea how to install it so enjoy this upgrade.

But I need to tell you this gear cover will only accommodate 32 pitch Spur Gears going for a
54 tooth up to a 58 tooth spur gear so keep that in mind.

author: Gearcortex

title: Bondtech BMG extruder mount for C-Bot

description.text:
This is a remixed version of Carl Feniak's 'direct drive' gantry for C-Bot/D-Bot printers, allowing for the mounting of the Bondtech BMG extruder. The main changes were the removal of the built-in direct drive system on top, the extension of the bottom heatbreak bracket, and the extension of the very top holes to stick over the new extruder. Plus, an alternate version!

Pro's:

  • You get to use a Bondtech BMG extruder on your C/D-bot!
  • If you go with the 'frontPlateAlt', you'll get 50mm of z-height back!

Con's:

  • You'll loose about 14mm on Y, based on how much more this sticks out.

Two versions are available

  • frontPlate : This has the extruder mounted to the top, and the heatbreak (I'm using a E3D-v6 Volcano) mounted to the bottom, with a bowden tube in-between. This was most similar to my original setup.
  • frontPlateAlt : This is designed to have the heatbreak mounted directly to the extruder itself. Based on how much the Bondtech sticks out from the gantry, I discovered the E3D-v6 heatbreak and hotend will clear the gantry, meaning, no more bowden-tube extension needed. Note, the volcano nozzle will stick down below the gantry by a few mm, allowing it to still print a-ok, but I am unsure if a 'normal' E3d hotend will be long enough for this configuration.

I also included a copy of the accompanying backplate & 'groove mount clamp' files that Carl designed.

You will need:

  • For either config, you'll need three M3x40mm socket head bolts. The BMG ships with 35mm bolts, and they're not long enough go through the printed pieces :-(
  • For the 'frontPlate', you'll need a bowden tube 94mm long, to run from the BMG into the heatbreak. You'll need a bowden adapter to plug into the base of the Bondtech.

Main Homepage:

  • http://www.bondtech.se/en/products/extruders/bmg-extruder

This is where I purchased mine in the US:

  • https://www.matterhackers.com/store/printer-accessories/bondtech-bmg-extruder-175\
  • https://www.matterhackers.com/store/printer-accessories/e3d-groove-mount-bowden-adapter-1.75mm

description.text:
At summer camp, I came over to one of these, but lifesized. I was so addicted playing the game, that I decided to create a miniature one! Make sure to print it with supports! I is so much better with, than without. There is also miniature balls to go with the table. If you have a XYZ printer, you should size it up to 8 for better roll. Print 11 of the balls.

Here is how you play "Carpetball"

first you set up five balls on each side. It is two players, so each player will set up their own design of balls.

Then you take the 11th ball and throw it at the other persons set of balls.

The first person to get all the other persons balls in the other persons box, wins.

if a tie, you go to four balls, than three, than two, than 1, and then if still a tie, you go back to four balls and so on.

If you have any questions, please leave a comment. Thanks!!!

I have a few LiPo batteries left over from drones I don't use anymore, and I thought to put those to use.
I opened the 12V craftsman battery, and removed the battery cells inside, and wired a XT60 connector where I can plug one of 4 cell LiPo battery (it should be a 3 cell for 12V equivalent, but don't have a 3 cell one)

print_settings.Printer:: Type A Machines 2015 Series 1

description.text:
This is my attempt at recreating NASA's 3D printed chainmail fabric/armor. I could not find any STL files online that did not fail, so I made my own in Fusion 360! I hope that this can be a fun project for this community.

If you have not seen the article/video, check them out:
https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=6816
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W4bZIf3B3gc

Enjoy!

Printer Brand:

Type A Machines

Printer:

Type A Machines 2015 Series 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Do NOT print with supports! It is a pain to take out and is unnecessary.

I recommend calibrating your printer's retraction settings before attempting this print as the majority of the middle section are many small circles.

When first stating the print, watch the first layer adhesion. If you do not get a good first layer, the print will fail. Restart and try again.

I have printed at 140% scale through 85% scale successfully, but the larger scales were stronger and looked better. Hopefully I will be able to print this on the Form 2 soon and test out how small this print can go!

Overview:

The base layers like to ooze together, but is easily broken by a craft knife.

Working/moving the print around will loosen up any small stinging that may occur during printing, but larger strings may need a craft knife.

Generally, the print will be stiff after removal, but will ease up during use.

Intro:

I was reading an article by NASA on their 3D printed fabric that they created on an SLS machine and wanted to make some for my own. This is the process if you would want to make changes or improvements:

Step 1:

Start with a 10x10mm rectangle and extrude 0.45mm (3 layers)

Step 2:

Make a sketch on the side of the previous extrusion. Draw a 45° line 1.7mm from the right and 5mm from the left. Next make a plane perpendicular to the line.

Step 3:

On the previously created plane, draw a 1.2mm circle 1.115mm from the line horizontally. Also add a line 5mm from the edge to revolve around. Using two sided revolve: 20° up, 70° down.

Step 4:

After creating a plane on from the revolve trajectory, make a sketch on that plane. First, make a perpendicular line from the end of the previous revolve. Now, draw a 5mm circle tangent to and connected to the endpoint of the line. Then trim off the circle after 30° from vertical and sweep the previous circle through the sketch.

Step 5:

Create another plane by offsetting from the end circle and project the center point from the circle before. Draw a sketch on the underside of the rectangle and make a center point of the rectangle. Using the three points just made ( center point of rectangle, center point of circle, and projected center point of circle) make a plane.

Step 6:

Draw on the plane just created. Draw a perpendicular line from the circle in Step 4 and vertical line from the center point of the rectangle; then connect the two lines end to end. Using these two lines, make a conic curve at 50%. Next, sweep the circle along this arc.

Step 7:

Circle Pattern the revolution and sweeps around the center.

Step 8:

Cut away the tails from the revolutions.

Step 9:

Make a 7.5mm diameter torus with a 1.2mm circle profile such that the torus is tangent to the first sweep.

Step 10:

Sketch on the top of the rectangle, make a 1x1mm rectangle and fill in the gap from the circular pattern.

Step 11:

Similar to Steps 5 and 6, make a plane using the intersection between the first sweep and the torus, the center point of a 1.2mm circle tangent to both edges and the projected center point of the circle. Next, on the plane draw a vertical line from the center point just created and a line from the endpoint to the intersection point from before. Using these two lines, make a conic curve at 50%. Next, sweep the circle along this arc.

Step 12:

Circle pattern Step 11 around the center of the rectangle.

Step 13:

Filet the edges of the rectangle by 0.6mm.

Step 14:

Cut away the middle by 1.5mm. This adds strength to the individual link.

Step 15:

Extrude the 1.5mm back using the created profile from Step 14.

Step 16:

Filet the edge between the corner sections by 0.5mm.

Step 17:

Cut away a small sections in the base to break the edge between the corner sections and the base on all four sides. This will be added back in later

Step 18:

Filet the longer edge by 0.3mm.

Step 19:

Add the base back from Step 17.

Step 20:

Smooth out the remaining edges on the top and sides using the filet tool.

Step 21:

Smooth out the remaining edges on the column using the filet tool.

Step 22:

Rectangular array the body using a spacing of 10.5mm.

Step 23:

Sketch on the underside of one of the links and make a rectangle that contains all of the links and extrude by 0.0001mm. This will allow the chainlink fabric to be one STL file, but this last extrusion will not be printed.

Final:

When exporting as an STL: the more chainlinks there are, the chances of your modeling software crashing increases exponentially. So, reduce the resolution in higher numbers of links.

Happy printing!

description.text: It's late. I'm bored. It's a sick frame and a sick company. So I thought, "why not?" Pretty simple trace 'n' extrude. As of now (7/15/17) I have not printed this but when I do (tomorrow I hope) I will add pics of it.

Hot end and parts cooling for the Folgertech Kossel Delta.

-Requires one 40mm fan (stock fan is suitable) for hot end cooling and one or two 30mm fans depending on configuration.
-All holes are set for 3mm screws

Edit: Added two renderings that should help with assembly

This assembly of parts is configurable to offer different options as needed by the end user which I will explain below...

File "MC1" is the physical mount for the stock extruder. This part is mandatory as it is the main support for your hot end and for the hot end cooler (file "MC2").

File "MC2" is the hot end cooling manifold and 40mm fan support. It also serves as the mounting base for the part cooler.

File "MC3" is the part cooling duct and 30mm fan support. You can print either one or two of these as the assembly can be configured to have one or two cooling ducts. If you choose one, it may be mounted on either the left or right side of the hot end cooler for more flexibility of the installation.

comments.text: I'm not sure, but there appears to be 2 fatal design flaws with the corner braces inside.  First, the center tube on the end with the handle running through it needs to spin freely just like the other side where it threads in. But it can't, this tube is fixed to two corner braces.  Next, the corner braces on one end strike the scissor legs as you open it about half way.  Bump, can't go further than half way open (and that's only if you break the screw handle off like I did, so that you can get past the first problem).

title: SLA Build platform using ball head

description.text:
I believe some makers already done this. This is a way to make the SLA printer build platform using tripod ball head. There isn't any printed part on this, although you can have some parts printed. This 3D model is a proof of concept, it isn't perfectly done to have proper tolerance, tap drill size, length, etc. The files are included so you can edit. I believe the standard screw-in dimension is 1/4 or 3/8 depend on the type of the ball head you will purchase. The lever cam lock used is in following link.
https://www.aliexpress.com/w/wholesale-bike-clamp.html?spm=2114.search0104.0.0.Iz5p2N&initiative_id=AS_20170715194505&site=glo&groupsort=1&SortType=price_asc&g=y&SearchText=bike+clamp
I will not provide the link for the ball head, because i can't guarantee which one works the best.
In the future I'll implement a quick release, so the print surface can be easily removed.

remixed_from.title: Hammerhead Magnetic Carriage for Delta printers

description.text:
This carriage was inspired by the Hammerhead Delta Carriage, but I needed a carriage with 48 mm spacing. The holes are aligned to a MGN12H linear rail carriage. The holes for the steel balls are designed for M3 threads and the back side holds a M3 nut. The balls are also angled down steeper for using longer rods.

Edit 7-6-17 Added 45mm spacing version.

Wilson 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Layer height and infill as needed. It is sturdy at 0.2 mm height and 20% infill.

Wanted to have some fun sculpting facial expressions. Cheeky defiance was an enjoyable choice.

Test print worked well enough without support, but the forearms at least would probably work nicer with support.

Also, I would highly recommend the version with the base unless your printer is very reliable, the hands don't have much of a base and lifted on my first print off the raft. Both version available for download.

Both versions around 900,000k tris. Let me know in the comments if you want lower poly versions for your particular printer. Would be nice to know if that is something that actually makes a difference for people's printers / computers.

An aquarium pump mount that connects to a wire utility shelf. I was tired of the pump vibrating and rattling around on the shelf, and wanted something more elegant than a bunch of tape, so I created this to get the pump up and out of the way.

This mount fits a Marina 75 (10-25 US Gal) aquarium air pump and a wire utility shelf with legs measuring 3/4" diameter.

No hardware required, the rubber feet sit in the circle guides and are secure. Install to the shelf at an upward angle and the weight of the pump keeps it locked in place.

description.text:
THESE WILL HAVE TO BE SCALED TO THE SIZE OF YOUR BODY TUBE!!!!!!

Just a few different model rocket designs that can be resized to fit whatever material you decide to use for the body tubes. Be careful when building and launching these models and make sure to abide by all laws and NAR regulations. I am not responsible for any injuries or damage that results from use.

Note that the GOLFTUBENOSE was not designed to couple into the parachute hold.

The V2 nose files and parachute hold files go together along with all of the fins except the GOLFTUBEFINS.

The GOLFTUBEFINS and GOLFTUBENOSE are made to fit the 1.25 inch golfclub tube that can be purchased from amazon.

https://www.amazon.com/Player-Supreme-Golf-Tubes-Dividers/dp/B0068PZ010/ref=sr_1_4?ie=UTF8&qid=1500186233&sr=8-4&keywords=golf%2Btube&th=1&psc=1

The motor adapter file is used to fit the 1 inch PVC motor into the 1.25 inch plastic golf club protector tube used for the rocket body.

Sugar rocket motors made using "The King of Random" motor manufacturing technique.

title: XR650L Handlebar Switch Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Allows mounting of waterproof switches to center of 1 1/8" bars. I used a DPDT switch for interlock override (offroad and emergency use). The SPST switch is for choosing which ignition curve I want (Ignitech programmable ignition). When printing the version in the photos, I'd forgotten to round the curves at the back of the plate. This has been corrected in my uploaded designs. I may be willing to upload modded designs for different clamping configs, as long as they are generally similar to this design. FYI, I used the 3-hole version for months without problems. I switched to the 2-hole version to allow easier access to the ignition switch.

Minimum 58mm between clamps needed.
Will cover outer clamp edges up to 118mm.
Minimum 8mm between bars and top of clamps needed.

What i used:
Tusk Universal Big Bar Clamp Kit
Pro-Taper Contour 1 1/8" Handlebar Carmichael Bend Black
Blue Sea 4155 DPDT
Blue Sea SPST
Switch Boot

description.text: This design is patterned after the slit style snow goggles worn by the Inuit people of the Arctic. The Inuit style basically has two colinear horizontal slits and were made of a single piece of bone, antler or wood with a sinew head strap. They were specifically fit to the wearer's face. The function of the narrow slits is to reduce snow glare and wind and can actually improve visual acuity. Since your field of view is significantly restricted DO NOT DRIVE OR PERFORM POTENTIALLY HAZARDOUS TASKS WHILE WEARING THESE GOGGLES.

comments.author: fsmaalouf

comments.text: If you are interested in splitting the model you can load it into a program like Meshmixer and set a cutting plane wherever you want. Export the model and then flip the plane and export it with a different name. The multi-color effect was accomplish by changing the filament color during the print. If I upload a bunch of different split files it will just clutter my model and require a method of attachment.
comments.author: fsmaalouf

comments.text:
Now those are some cool shades.
Do you know offhand if the the slit polarizes the light at all? Light off the ground should be horizontally polarized, so to block the most glare you'd need vertical slits. But you'd need a lot in order to see a decent field of view. One horizontal slit is probably easier to make by hand but I'd suspect that vertical slits would do a better job.

comments.text: Thanks. I have a different design that I plan to upload soon, I'm Just trying to get a good fit. It has a vertical slit for each eye.

description.text:
We have a small cat - it's a three year tomcat from the animal shelter near. He's cute but has bad habits. He always in the night opens all drawer in kitchen to inspect the whole room every centimeter he can get to. He has a lot of toys, we play with him every day, he is not alone and has a companion.

But to prevent him to get always to the trash can to get everything out of it, i designed a simple lock for the drawers. It must not be screwed or glued. It simply connect the lowest drawer with the one above so he need more force to open them. This worked for us great.
Sorry Knopfi ;-)

I designed this using Fusion 360 hobbyist license.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

title: Mobile Phone Dock with passive Boom Sound (NEW Add-On)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a Mobile Phone Dock with passive Boom Sound. I designed this dock around the Google Pixel and Google Pixel XL mobile phones (with and without Incipio shockproof cases). However any mobile phone will fit by scaling the dock on the Z axis (when printed on its side).

IMPORTANT: In your slicer software use Z axis scaling (when printed on its side) and make sure Uniform Scaling is not selected. The aim is to stretch the part along its width and not increase the overall size.

Use this simple formula to scale for your phone’s width: (P + 4) / 0.8 = Z axis scale %. P stands for the Phone width in millimeters (mm). For example for a phone with the width of 86 mm: (86 + 4) / 0.8 you will set the Z axis scale to 112.5 %

Note for Boom Sound
This is a passive sound amplification through the resonance chamber built into the dock and extended to the side screw-on pipes. This dock was designed for mobile phones with bottom firing speakers. You can experiment with 2 different length side screw-on pipes (2 included).

Add-on Extensions
You can create your own add-on extensions to the sides screw-on pipes.

UPDATES
23/07/17 - I included a side add-on extension (Horn_01.stl) and tested with significant improvement in reproducing a richer sound from the bottom firing speaker of the Google Pixel mobile.This worked particularly well with Smooth Jazz and Acoustic music.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Designed in: Fusion 360
Sliced: Simplify3D
Material: PLA

Temperature

  • Heated Base 50 c
  • Primary Extruder: 205 c

Rafts/Supports

  • Dock (No/Yes)
  • Support Pipe (No/No)
  • 2 x Side Screw-On Pipes (Yes/No)
  • 2 x Horns (No/Yes)

You may choose to print the DOCK at 0.2 mm or even 0.25 mm for faster print however I have only tested the DOCK design at 0.15 mm layer (70 mm/sec). Overall print time at 0.15 mm was around 24 hrs combined (for DOCK and other parts printed, excluding the new 2 x Horns).

UPDATES
23/07/17 - I printed the new 2 x Horns (Horn_01.stl) at 0.2 mm (50 mm/sec) for an additional 24 hrs. Total print time to date is 48 hrs at the resolutions listed.

author: calinsyd

description.text:
For the latest jet engine for passenger planes, the Bypass Ratio is bigger and bigger to improve the engine-performance.
In order for one of them, the 3-spool system is developed. The 3D model for explaining this system was designed and made imaging "Trent" series engines..
The points of the design are;

  1. For the rotation of each spool, the ball bearing method and the dummy bearing method are prepared.

  2. All stator vanes are omitted this time, because of avoiding rub of vanes and blades. And each rotor is designed with support so that it can be printed as one-piece.
    The blade angle is made to agree in the spool rotational direction (View from Rear).

    • HP Spool: Clockwise
    • IP Spool: Counter Clockwise
    • LP Spool: Counter Clockwise
  3. In addition, some parts that printing is considered difficult without support, are prepared STL file with support. The last of two digits of the file name is identified as "ws". In order to ease understanding about the contents of each part and the assembly order, parts breakdown and list are prepared.

Download files includes;
-files: STL Files
-images: Parts Breakdown for assembly Aid
-Excel File: Parts List

Purchase Parts Information;
-Bearings (Can be used Dummy BRGs instead of the followings, See Parts List)
DDL-1370ZZ (7 x 13 x 4) 2ea - For IP-Spool
689ZZ (9 x 17 x 5) 2ea - For HP-Spool
6900ZZ (10 x 22 x 6)　2ea - For LP-Spool

-Aluminum Tubes
See Parts List

-Screws
Micro screws M1.4x3L - Appox. 50 ea - Direct screw-in to 1 mm dia hole (No nut),
Screws M2 x 6L - 6 ea, See Parts List

Assembly Points

  • Standard Skill (such as Drilling, Tapping, Filing, Tightening, Painting and Gluing etc) is needed and perseverance too.

Total Net Print Time: Approx. 42HR

  • (Estimated as case of PLA, 0.4mm Nozzle, 0.2mm Layer Height, 40% infill and No raft and support)
    Note: When at actual print, each parameter may be adjusted.

[Update]
Optional Fan; https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2794855 - 2018.2.15
Modified Rotor; https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2833968 - 2018.3.21

idbox

description.text:
Designed especially for Ultimaker 3 and 3 Extended, but will work with others too. No need to stick or damage your 3D printer. Yes, Ultimakers have their own camera, but if you are used to have full control over your Raspberry Pi and Pi Cam (especially for distant monitoring outside the local network), there is a choice for you now… ;)

BOM:
• Raspberry Pi Zero W
• Pi Camera
• 2 pairs of 20mm M3 screws and nuts
• all of these 3D printed parts
• installed surveillance platform of your choice (tip: OctoPrint works fine, even if you use only camera part ;) )

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

Print all of it it with standard 0.4mm nozzle and 0.2mm layers. Only „Pi_Zero_case_bottom.stl“ needs some supports. My is 3D printed from Fillamentum Iceland Blue PLA.

There are no great tolerances, because I wanted to have everything easy snap fitting. So if your 3D printer is callibrated different way, be ready for a little grinding. Also, the difference between the thickness of left and right side case cover of my UM3 is 0.5mm, so maybe yours is also a bit different. ;)

  • 2x Bearing Outer 1
  • 2x Bearing Outer 2

Requirements:

  • 4x 608 Bearing
  • 4x M3 Screw
  • 4x M3 Nut

Construction:
Insert the ball bearing between "Bearing Outer 1" and "Bearing Outer 2"
The "Bearing Outer" you insert between two frames and screw it with the M3 screw and nut
Finally put the foots under the frames

Optional:
Adhesive can be used to bond frame and foot. Do not use for "Bearing Outer"!

Remark:
My filament roller has been printed at a very fast speed and no postprint process to show the general construction
Quick calculation and fast tests showed that 3kg roles are supported (No warranty and guarantee because materials may vary widely in texture and depending on the pressure)

screw_head_teeth = 8

Important: I scaled all the parts to 200% before printing! This way, the Batarang will have a more appropriate size. Also I can't tell if the parts fit together at the normal scale.

I recommend you to print the Base and Top parts at around 50% infill and with the logo facing upwards. You'll have to use supports, but it looks way better like that.
The wing has to be printed twice (once mirrored) and can be printed with only 10% infill. Of course you can go higher with that, if you'd like your Batarang to be a bit heavier.
I made my first print with a layer height of 0.3mm, but I'd go for 0.2mm or 0.1mm just for the blade to look a bit cleaner.
Let me know if you have any issues or suggestions regarding the model!
Have fun printing your very own Batarang. Let me see your results ;)

description.text:
Allows a torch to be clamped to the lathe bed for wood turning.
Helps when hollowing out bowls or doing hollow forms.

The clip is for a Cat eye H34 mount torches (should fit EL530, EL520, EL510, EL500, EL450, EL320, EL300, EL220, EL210, EL200, EL135, EL130, EL110, EL100, MC200, EL830RC, EL820RC, EL610RC, EL600RC, and EL010).

Requires an M6 40mm bolt (hex head) and nut for the base, and an M4 16mm bolt and nut for the clip joint.
These bolt sizes can be adjusted in the .scad file.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed with PETG. Only the clip needs support (to base only).

After cleanup

  1. Put the M6 bolt through the platform
  2. Push the M6 nut into the base
  3. Screw platform and base together to pull the bolt head and nut into the recesses
  4. Put the clip joint pillar between the platform pillars and align the holes
  5. Push the M4 nut into the pillar
  6. Screw the M4 bolt through the three pillars

author: 3D-IN

description.text:
First of all: Scott made an awesome job and many thanks for that.
Some points where a little bit annoying on his extruder parts and one of them was the fact, that the insert brass nuts where pulled out, when fasten them to much.

There was also some annoying leeway in the hotend fitting which let it turn unintentionally.

And last of all: I had to made some solderings to the optical endswitch, because of a plug, that doesn't fit to the original extruder mount.

So look at the photos:
I made a redesign, which solves all these problems.
Hotend now better fits, additional fixing-screws at the retainer, without retraction of the insert nuts.
More space for a standard optical switch without need of soldering. As a positive sideeffect, you now can remove it without loosen the cables.

Update V3.0:
Made a designchange to use the Probe on the opposite side of the extruder-mount. I needed this, because my probe went outside the hotbed when reaching the endstop.
Now you can use it vise versa, if you want. Just flip the retainer by 180 degrees. Thats it.
Made some mass-reduction too.
Removed the center-insert-nut and changed it to a normal M3-nut.

Have fun with it.

Printer:

MeCreator 2

Resolution:

0,15 mm

Infill:

50%
